text: FRANK MOSES lies awake in bed, waiting for the beginning of the day. 4:59 AM changes to 5:00 and he gets up.

Wearing a tattered bathrobe, Frank watches his coffee brew. He's compact and in good shape with broad shoulders and close-cropped hair. He could be 50s, could be 60s - he has this grizzled quality that makes it tough to tell.

Like the rest of the house, the living room is only nominally furnished: a sofa, lamp, and a shelf of records Frank cranks out a set of pushups. Frank cranks out jumping jacks. Frank cranks out sit-ups. Not crunches... sit-ups.
Frank eats two eggs and dry toast at the small table. One small frying pan, one plate, one knife, and one fork are set in the rack to dry.

Wearing a devastatingly uncool sun hat, Frank picks a lone weed from the dirt around his roses, then stands back to admire them: they're withered and sickly. He looks over sourly at the roses next door: a dazzling array of color. A young MOM comes out of the house with a baby ina stroller.
Hi, Mr. Moses. Frank puts on a smile and gives her a wave.
Frank contemplates a shelf full of cans of BEANS. He starts loading up his cart - at least 50 cans.
Frank loads up 50 cans of SPINACH.
A teenage CASHIER eyes Frank as she rings him up.
Guess you like beans.
They're all right.
Frank puts his groceries away, revealing that his cabinet are already filled with cans. He carefully places the new ones in back, rotating his stock.

Frank goes through his mail, tossing the junk, leaving only one letter: a green envelope. He tears it open: a check from the U.S. Government. Pulling an LP from a shelf of vinyl records, Frank drops it onto the stereo and lowers the needle. Picking up the phone, he takes a deep breath and dials.
May I have your social?
Five four three, six six, two two nine one. Pension services please.
Thank you Mr. Moses. Please hold for your representative. There's a series of CLICKS as the call is transferred.

Rows of cubicles stretch out beneath the fluorescent lighting, filled with operators on headsets.  3. SARAH ROSS, older then 30, but we won't say more than that, sits in a cubicle spruced up with spider plants, postcards, and pictures. She's pretty, conservative looking, and bored.
Hi, this is Sarah.
Hey. It's Frank Moses. She immediately brightens.
Hey Frank. What's going on?
Nothing really. I was just calling because I didn't get my check again.
Oh jeez. I can't believe they haven't worked this out. I'll make sure they get another one out today.
It's no big deal. Whenever you get around to it.
I'm just sorry this happened again. Frank leans back, tearing up his check.
What are you gonna do? A pause draws out between them. FRANK (cont'd) Well, I guess...
So how are your roses doing? Frank hurriedly answers...
It's a massacre. I've got rust and mold. Now I've sprayed them so much they have chemical burns.
You try soapy water?  He lights
That works?
I swear. Hey what are you listening to? up.
It's The Chirping Crickets; Buddy Holly's first album in '57.
Never heard it.
It's before your time. Hell, it's before my time, but it's an amazing record. It has the first released version of "That'll Be the Day." She smiles.
You have a lot of free time, don't you?
Little bit. Yeah. (beat) I don't have the foggiest idea what to do with myself.
What did you do before you retired?
I was in the diplomatic corps. This strikes a chord.
Really? I'd give anything to travel more.
Believe me, it's not so fun when it's business.
I just want to quit my job and move to Spain for six months.
You should. You'd have an amazing time.
I can see why retirement would be hard. Maybe what you need is to fall in love with something new. Frank smiles.
Yeah. I guess so. An annoying looking woman with a pinched face appears at the edge of Sarah's cubicle.
My supervisor. I gotta go. Sarah hangs up and aggressively stares the woman down. SARAH (cont'd) What?
Frank sits on the floor of the darkened room, repeatedly bouncing a rubber ball against the wall and catching it.
Sarah sits at the table in her kitchen eating dinner alon and reading a spy thriller.
Heading inside, Frank sorts through his mail. Two pieces of junk and another green envelope. He smiles.
Sarah's on her headset.
You need excitement. A passion. Something that makes you feel alive.
Frank dumps a can of spinach into a pot.
Excitement is overrated.
How can you say that? Everyone needs excitement. The most I get is fighting with my mother.
What about?
She keeps trying to set me up on blind dates with her bridge partners' kids. She just told me she's worried I'm gay. (suddenly concerned) I'm not, by the way.
Good to know.
I think we need to talk about something else. Frank can't help but grin.
What are you reading this week?
Just a romance.
What?
It doesn't matter.
(teasing) Come on. There's a long guilty beat.
It's called Love's Savage Secret. Frank mulls this over.
Is it good?
It's terrible! I love it! The lead is a sort of a Britney/Lindsay character marooned on this island with her tennis pro and a prince.
Who's Britney Lindsay?
Very funny. Frank was serious, but lets it go.
Hey, hold on a second, I want you to hear this. He carefully puts on a record and drops the needle. Buddy Holly's THAT'LL BE THE DAY echoes out. They both listen.
I like this.
It's cool, right?
Yeah. They listen for another minute. SARAH (cont'd) I better be getting back to work.
Yeah, course. I didn't mean to keep you.
I'm glad you did. I'll talk to you soon?
You bet.
Frank sits reading Love's Savage Secret, biting his lip as he turns the pages.
Frank climbs into bed and turns out the light. The clock changes from 10:59 to 11:00. He lies in the darkness, staring up at the ceiling, waiting to get tired THAT'LL BE THE DAY, fades to a close.
That'll be the day-ay-ay that I die.
The house is quiet and still against the suburban night.
Frank lies on his bed, staring at the ceiling. It's 3:22. He picks up the glass beside his bed, but it's empty. Getting up, he shrugs into his tattered bathrobe.

Frank shuffles out of his bedroom and down the hall to the bathroom. But as he passes the stairs, the CAMERA HOLDS on the darkness of the stairwell... ...and the darkness suddenly comes alive with motion: THR COMMANDOS in hi-tech body armor, night-vision, and weapon are right there. From a small case, the leader takes out a full syringe. The second reaches past him with a snoop scope linked to his heads up display: the hall is clear, the door at the far end swinging closed. They move silently into the hall, listening to the WATER RUN: the leader with the syringe, the second empty-handed ready for the take down, the third with a machine pistol. The bathroom door stands ajar, spilling out bright light. The commandos lift their night-vision as they move down the hall, past the guest room, closing in. WHAM! They kick in the door revealing... ...the empty bathroom... ...as Frank steps out of the darkened guest room behind them in his robe and bare feet. The three men whip around, startled... WHAP! The commando closest to Frank goes down.  9. The second swings, but his legs are swept from under him, Frank's heel crushing his throat as he hits the floor. The leader lunges with the syringe, but it's twisted out of his hand and suddenly in his arm... plunger pressed. Staring at Frank, the commando's eyes flutter and drop. Frank is left standing alone amidst the bodies. He isn't even breathing hard. He crouches down, looking them over without emotion.

Frank grabs a sledge hammer at the bottom of the stairs, steps to the middle of the room and swings. CRACK! A thin layer of cement shatters. Sweeping fragments away, he pulls out a buried locker. Inside are bricks of cash and an array of passports. Frank quickly stuffs a satchel. Then he unwraps an old 1911 model .45 semiautomatic and adds it as well. Finally he grabs an old set of miliary dog tags and puts them in his pocket.
Frank finishes dressing, picks up the phone, and dials.
May I have your social?

Five four three, six six, two two nine one. Status RED. He hangs up and heads out. But the phone RINGS. He stops, listening to it ECHOING EERILY through the hous Finally he picks it up, holding it to his ear, waiting.

Frank Moses? Without answering, Frank moves beside the window, up against the wall, slightly pulling back the drapes and glancing out.  10. A white van is parked at an odd angle across the street, the back door open.
POV from inside the van: WE SEE the bit of curtain move. CLICK: Suddenly it's the same view IN INFRARED, Frank's heat signature clear as day.

Frank catches a glint of light from the van. Exploding into motion, he drops the phone and runs all out down the hall as... PFFT! PFFT! PFFT! Three 40mm grenades are launched into the house and... BOOM! A fireball roars down the hall as... Frank SMASHES through a second floor window...
.. hits the roof, and spills into the yard in a shower of glass.

Stepping from the back of the van, a FOURTH COMMANDO slin his six-round grenade launcher and raises binoculars, surveying the destruction. Catching a glimpse of motion he lowers the lenses... ...Frank is twenty feet away, charging straight at him... The commando scrambles for his sidearm but... WHAM! ...-he's tackled straight back into the van. The rear doors are pulled closed, the engine starts, and the van pulls out, disappearing in to the night.
Boston rises in the distance behind this cute suburb by the Charles River.  11.
Sarah heads up the walk with a guy a full head shorter than she is.
I had a nice time tonight. Thank you. FRED watches her unlock the door.
Aren't you going to invite me in?
Sorry Fred. Say hi to your mom for me.

Kicking off her shoes, Sarah slides out of her dress and pulls on an oversized shirt already laid out on a chair beside Love's Savage Secret. Settling in, she cracks the book, but then thinks again and gets up. Walking into the kitchen, she grabs a glass, ice, and a pour of bourbon. Then she shakes her head...
Fred. ...and pours a little more. Heading back to her book, she passes Frank. Shrieking, she jumps, the glass smashing on the floor. Sarah grabs a vase to defend herself as Frank puts up his hands.
Hey! Hey! It's Frank Moses.
Stay back!
It's me. (beat) You eat Tasty Cakes for lunch and your mom thinks you're gay. She stares, worlds colliding, her fear turning to anger.  12.
Jesus Christ! She protectively pulls down her shirt to cover more of herself, backing away. SARAH (cont'd) What the hell are you doing here? Frank steps forward, hands still up.
You have to get out of the house.
What are you talking about?
It's not safe here. It's my fault and I'll explain, but right now, I need you to come with me. She stares at him nervously.
I think you'd better leave. He picks up a small suitcase from the floor. SARAH (cont'd) That's my bag.
I packed for you. She looks around, reeling.
Did you... do my dishes? Frank's clearly guilty. Pulling it together, she puts on an authoritative tone.
Frank. I always liked you. But I'm not about to... Sarah freezes in fear as he draws his .45. But he's staring past her out the window, where a car pulls up across the street.
Right now, out the back.  13.
I'm not going anywhere! Frank's torn, feeling the seconds ticking by, not sure how to handle this.
I was never a diplomat. I was in the CIA, and someone is trying to kill me. That means there's been surveillance. They've listened to our phone calls and they're going to come after you as leverage.
I'm calling the police. The car doors open and three men get out, crossing the street toward Sarah's.
Frank's behind the wheel with Sarah's purse on his lap, going through it as he smoothly drives, tossing a nail file and her can of pepper spray out the window.

This couldn't be more different from how I hoped to meet you, you know, if we ever even did meet. He comes up with her cell phone and tosses it out too. FRANK (cont'd) But things happen and I think it's important to be flexible. He pauses, taking a breath, knowing it's not going well, but really trying. FRANK (cont'd) You know what I mean? Frank glances back for reassurance. REVEAL Sarah, tied and gagged in the back seat, staring daggers at him.
As dawn breaks, Frank pulls into this quiet, anonymous ranch-style motel.  14.
Sarah sits on the bed watching Frank warily as he unties her wrists then reaches for the tape on her mouth.
Sorry. He RIPS it off.
Ow!
You want some water? She looks at him, scared but in control.
If you let me go right now, I won't press charges.
I'm not kidnapping you.
What do you think you just did!
You were in danger.
No I wasn't! Even if you aren't completely full of crap and people are after you, no one cares about me.
They know I call you. They've listened.
So what? Frank can't quite look at her, embarrassed. SARAH (cont'd) What?
(dying) They know... I like you. She isn't sure how to respond.
You hardly know me.  15.
I know you. She looks away.
If you're really CIA, why don't you just call them?
I don't know how these guys found me. (beat) I have to see someone. I need you to stay here until I get back.
You just want me to sit here?

You'll be perfectly safe. No one knows where you are. He picks up the tape and tears off a fresh piece. She looks at him in confusion and fear. FRANK (cont'd) I'll be back soon. She realizes what's about to happen.
No! You crazy kidnapping pervert sonofabitch. You can kiss my... Frank tapes her mouth.

WILLIAM COOPER, 30s, sits at a desk, tearing open a manil envelope with latex gloves. He wears a conservative suit and tie, but his haircut and bearing are those of a soldier. Pulling out several 8x10 black and white photos, he drops them on the desk: they're of a man and woman in a tryst.

Cooper takes out a sheet of plastic with a dozen blonde hairs pressed onto it.  16. Lifting them one by one with tweezers, he places them on a brush, in the shower drain, in the dust on the floor. As his phone VIBRATES, he checks the number and answers.

Hey hon. He takes out plastic sheets with individual fingerprints pressed into them. Laying one on the corner of the mirror, he peels back the plastic, leaving the print. COOPER (cont'd) No I think I'll be on time tonight.

Cooper walks past someone struggling to maintain his precarious tip-toe balance on a chair, his hands secured behind his back and his neck in a noose. COOPER (cont'd) Okay, well I'll talk to the boys about it when I get home.
Cooper lays fingerprints on the left side of the bed and nightstand. COOPER (cont'd) I will. I promise.

Cooper walks back in. COOPER (cont'd) Okay. Love you. Bye. Desperate, the MAN from the tryst photos tries to look down at Cooper while keeping balanced. He's 50s, heavyset but well groomed, wearing a suit that cost thousands.
(Eastern European accent) Listen. I can make you rich. Cooper ignores him, making a note on his PDA. MAN (cont'd)
Cooper glances up with no reaction.  17.

Actually, I don't have the slightest idea. He kicks the chair out from under him. Legs dance wildly in the air behind Cooper as his phone buzzes again. He checks the text: "FRANKLIN SQ. 10 MIN." The legs still. Cooper removes the padded restraints from the wrists of the dead man and heads out.
At least that's the sign. But there's no green. Just cracked pink stucco as far as the eye can see. SUPERED TITLE: WASHINGTON, D.C.

JOE MATHESON sits in a wheelchair in his small one-room apartment, struggling to reach the rabbit ears of a tiny crap TV. Joe's a man from another era - 90s and frail - but his white hair is neatly parted and slicked back, and he wear a three-piece suit with a gold chain and pocket-watch. Smacking the side of the television, he shakes it, making a hell of a racket until...
Is that thing acting up again? Joe glances back and smiles at the cute NURSE in his doorway.
Yeah. Can you give it a shot Marna?
Of course. He rolls out of her way and settles in to watch as she's forced to lean way over to reach the antennas. MARNA (cont'd) I don't see why you don't move these lower. He admires her ass.  18.
Better picture. Try a little to the left. (beat) That's getting there. REVEAL Frank stepping into the doorway, taking in the scene. He clears his throat. Joe looks over as the nurse straightens up.
Well, I think that does it Mr. Matheson. She walks out, placing a hand on Joe's arm as she passes. MARNA (cont'd) See you later.
Thanks Marna. Frank watches her go, marveling.
You're unbelievable. Joe grins devilishly, struggling to his feet and pulling Frank into a huge hug.
Your timing is terrible, Kid. I don't see you in forever and when you finally show, you're cutting into my action.
Is that why you're always telling me not to come? Frank helps him sit back down.
It's goddamned embarrassing you seeing me like this.
Who do you think you're talking to, Joe?
I never thought it would happen to me. Getting old. The things we did, I never thought I'd still be alive. Hell, I can't believe you're alive.  19.
Yeah, well, I retired.
You? Ha! Can't be. I remember recruiting this wet-behind-the-ears army punk like it was yesterday. Frank can't help but smile. JOE (cont'd) What'd you do? Marry the girl next door? Frank hesitates.
Sarah lies on the bed, mouth taped, hands and feet tied to the bed frame, furiously struggling to get loose.
Not exactly. (beat) I got a visit from a wet team last night.
(stunned) Jesus. How'd that go?
You have someone you trust in the Company who can run some IDs?
Sure. Got the prints? Frank tosses him a squishy plastic bag. Joe peers inside, disgusted. JOE (cont'd) You know there was a time this was a gentleman's game.

Moms walk babies, a pack of kids kicks around a soccer ball, and parents casually watch the action.  20. Cooper walks along the edge of the game, stopping beside a heavy, balding MAN, 50s, in a conservative suit holding a newspaper. They both watch the soccer game.
We had an action go south. I need you to clean it up. He hands Cooper the newspaper. MAN (cont'd) This is from the top. It's off the books. Total blackout. No logs. No records. Are we clear?
Yes sir. Cooper opens the newspaper, revealing a file. The first page is a long-lensed photograph of Frank watering his roses.
That's your primary target. There was a previous team. They are dead. Cooper flips through the file, reading.
He was CIA.
Is that a problem? Cooper closes the file and tucks the paper under his arm.
No.
Joe and Frank sit on a small patio in the shade. Joe's on a cell phone taking notes.
Okay. You too. Thanks. He hangs up. JOE (cont'd) It was a South African team. Very elite. They only worked for major governments.  Joe gives He passes 21.
Christ. him a hard look.
What the hell did you do?
Nothing! I'm out! I've been sitting on my ass killing roses.
One of them is also a print match to an NYPD crime scene. A woman was killed a couple months back. his notes to Frank, but nothing clicks.
I don't know her. ___(angry) This doesn't make any sense. Who would come after me now?
Give me a day. I'll make some calls. See what I can find out.
Just be careful. These guys are motivated.
(laughing) Hell, Kid. I'm ninety years old with stage IV liver cancer. What do I have to be afraid of?

This cramped high-tech nerve center is filled with computers, data and video feeds. THOMAS and JACKSON, 30, cold and hard, stand with Cooper, sorting through the detritus of Frank's life spread out on tables: phone bills, mail, trash, receipts...
In six months this guy didn't make a single personal phone call. No credit cards, no voicemail, no computer, no TV.  22.
Run the ten pay phones closest to his house. A phone RINGS and Thomas grabs it.
Yeah? (to Cooper) D.C. Metro's responding to a 911 call from one Sarah Ross.
Three police cruisers and an ambulance are out front, lights flashing. POLICE OFFICERS have cordoned off the area.
Sarah sits on the tailgate being checked out by a PARAMED as a YOUNG COP stands protectively beside her. She's stressed out and shaken.
I need to call my family.
Just finishing up. He strips the blood pressure cuff and the cop helps her u
We'll get you a phone, but they want me to take you downtown for a statement. There's also a bunch of federal guys who want to talk to you.
Is this going to take long? He grins.
Definitely.
Sarah follows the cop around the corner to his cruiser.
Hey!  23. An older, PLAINCLOTHES DETECTIVE, approaches.
Where are you taking her?
(confused) What do you mean?
Cooper looks down from the rooftop, watching the two cops through binoculars.
(into headset) Take him out.
The detective's startled as, PFFT! PFFT! he takes two in the chest from a SILENCED PISTOL in the young cop's hand. Stunned, Sarah backs away, but he grabs her, jabbing a hypodermic into her arm.

No! He pops the trunk of the cruiser, forcing her inside... ...but suddenly the cop's grabbed from behind. CRUNCH! He falls... ...revealing Frank. Sarah woozily stares at him and then the two dead bodies. SARAH (cont'd) You just killed that man?
Yes. He pulls open the syringe and tastes what's inside.
Am I going to die?
Just sleep. You probably need it. He helps her into the passenger side of the cruiser.  24.
I am very tired. Sliding behind the wheel he pulls out. Sarah leans against him, watching the world slide by with heavy lids. SARAH (cont'd) Frank?
Yes.
This is just like in Love's Savage Secret, where the tennis pro saves her from the Jihadists. ...and she's out.

head_text.subj: MPH SENDING BOTH CARS SPINNING IN A SHOWER OF GLASS.

text: Opening his door for cover, Cooper's unloading rounds into Frank's police cruiser. But as he whips out his magazine and reloads, Frank pops back up behind the wheel, peeling out in shriek of burnin rubber and twisted metal. Cooper tracks the cruiser, FIRING until it disappears around a corner.
Driving with one hand, Frank's on the radio.
Shots fired! Officer down! sth and Douglas! Suspect is a white male, 30's, dark suit, white shirt...

Back in the car, Cooper punches it, peeling around the corner after Frank, accelerating fast, but then abruptly SCREECHING to a stop. Frank's cruiser is parked on the street. Jumping from his car, gun ready, Cooper approaches, angli around to see inside... it's empty.  25. Taking his time, Cooper surveys the scene: Frank's car hissing coolant; a dead-empty street of small businesses. Whipping up his gun at motion, Cooper looks down his sigh at a CLERK in the flower shop in front of him, staring at him in wide-eyed fear through the open door. On both sides of Cooper, police cars turn onto the street screeching to a halt 100 feet back and spilling out cops. CoP Drop your weapon! Cooper weighs his options. Then he puts down the gun and raises his hands.
Stepping into sight with Sarah unconscious in one arm, Frank moves his .45 from the clerk to cover Cooper. The two men stare each other down.
(to the clerk) Out the back. Car keys. Now.
Joe Matheson's on the phone, worried, jotting something on a piece of paper.

I appreciate it. Okay. Bye. He folds the paper and scrawls Frank's name on it. Rolling to his dressing table, Joe straightens his tie, combs his hair back, and picks up his wallet and keys. Behind him, the door to his room opens and two men in suits step inside, pulling the door shut. Joe coldly eyes them in the mirror, slipping the paper into the dresser. One SUIT takes out a gun. The other picks up a pillow.
So it's like that then?
Yeah. It's like that. Joe nods, resigned.  26.
Frank sits in an SUV parked in front of an apartment building, sipping coffee. Across the river are the skyscrapers of Manhattan. Sarah stirs, waking in the passenger seat beside him.
Hey. She looks around, disoriented and panicky. FRANK (cont'd) Take it easy. You're okay. Off balance, she tries to calm down.
How... (beat) How long was I asleep?
About six hours. Coffee? She nervously looks him over and takes it.
Thanks. (beat) Thanks for saving me. He nods. She takes a sip.
How'd you get free?
I worked the headboard loose and burned through the rope with the heater's pilot light. Frank's impressed. SARAH (cont'd) I'm sorry I didn't believe you.
I'm sorry I tied you up. A beat.
Who's doing this?  27.
I don't know. She's having trouble grasping it all.
I'm supposed to have dinner with my parents tonight.
You're not going to make it. And if you call them, they're going to get hurt. Do you understand? She nods, unnerved by his intensity.
What happens now?
The men who came after me killed the daughter of a woman who lives in that building. I'm hoping we can figure out the connection. She considers this.
I guess you're going to be stuck with me for a while. Frank looks at her in surprise.
Yeah. Sarah absently picks a piece of car safety glass out of her hair and looks questioningly at Frank. He shrugs.
Frank and Sarah stop at number 2D.
One sec. He opens his satchel and grabs the duct tape. FRANK (cont'd) Hold this. Then he takes out a drug bottle and fills a syringe, tapping out the bubbles.  28.
What are you doing? I thought we were going to talk to her!
We are. This'll just help.
The woman lost her daughter! She grabs the syringe. SARAH (cont'd) People are basically nice, Frank. She knocks on the door. He looks at her sourly.
That hasn't been my experience.
I think maybe I should do the talking.
Sarah and Frank sit on the sofa opposite MRS. CHAN, 60, who hands Sarah a photo of her smiling 30ish daughter.
She gave me this picture the week before she died. It was the last time I saw her... The police said it was just a burglary. Sarah puts a sympathetic hand on her arm.
We don't know it was anything other than that. You said Stephanie was a reporter? Mrs. Chan nods, choked up. SARAH (cont'd) Do you know what she was working on?
No. Sarah notices writing on the back of the photo: a cross followed by 1980 1745 126.
What's this number?  29.
I don't know. It's Stephanie's writing. I tried dialing it. The police had no idea. Frank stares at the numbers.
Frank and Sarah walk through the foyer.
It's a dead drop. That code is a call number for a book.
Call numbers start with letters.
Library of Congress does. Harvard- Yenching is a system for Asian language books. 1980 is the number for Christian literature: the cross.
How could you possibly know that?
Wo zhu zai Zhongguo ji nian qian.
Christ. You speak Chinese?
I was there for a few years.
Studying call numbers, Frank pulls a book from the shelf, and opens it. Inside is a single sheet of paper: a typed list of almost twenty names.
Unbelievable. One of them is "FRANK MOSES." SARAH (cont'd) What is this?
I don't know.  30.
Sarah sits at a terminal with the list between them.
Hank Maestriano... died two weeks ago in a car crash. Daniel McGinty, heart attack last week. Aaron Burke... suicide four days ago.
Jesus. It's a hit list. Pulling out a cell phone, he quickly dials.
This one guy is still alive, I think. Gabriel Loeb. He flies cargo planes.
(into phone) Who is this? (pause) Marna? Where's Joe?
Joe's nurse MARNA stands shaken and stammering. Behind her, Joe's apartment is swarming with cops.
Mr. Moses?
What happened?
Mr. Matheson has disappeared. There's... there's blood everywhere. She silently breaks down.
Looks like two shooters... Frank's reeling.
No...
They found a note with your name on it. He talked about you all the time. He loved you like a son.  31.
Marna. What did it say?
It was just two words. (beat) The Company. Frank hangs up, stunned. He's beside himself.
Joe's dead. She reaches out to him, but he gets up. He's cold with fury, stirred to the core of his being. FRANK (cont'd) Those bastards are going to pay.
Who?
Striding across the seal of the Central Intelligence Agen set into the polished marble floor... ...is Cooper.
Cooper stands with Frank's file across from a RESEARCH CLERK at a computer.
This man is NOT a retired Asian block analyst who's been out of the field for thirty years.
That's what it says.
Two guards check Cooper's paperwork, then nod to an old RECORDS KEEPER. The old man dials in a combination and the guards swing open a huge steel door, revealing a cavernous file room.  32.
These records have never been computerized. They never will be.
Frank moves through the throngs of people exiting the terminal, accidentally bumping into a woman in the crowd.

Excuse me. Pressing on, he flips through the pocketbook of the woman he just bumped. Reaching Sarah in line at the ticket counter, he hands her a driver's license that looks remarkably like her. FRANK (cont'd) Cynthia Bolt. Memorize the date of birth.
Will you tell me where we're going now?
To see Marvin. Confused, Sarah takes out the list, finding the name.
Marvin Frye?
He's the only name on that list I know. We worked together before he sectioned out. He knows things.
Frank, he died two years ago ina fire.
He's died before.
What does that mean?
Marvin's... peculiar. Extremely paranoid and dangerous. He's not like other people.  33.
You're not like other people. Frank considers. It's a fair point.
Right. Well, Marvin's less like other people. A TICKET AGENT waves them over.
I'm sorry things are so slow, our computers are down. Someone spilled coffee on the server. Frank takes the last sip of a jumbo java.
No kidding.
Cooper drops a six-inch-thick stack of paper stamped "TOP SECRET" onto the table.
Frank Moses's real file. Thomas flips it open. Page after page has been blacked out, line by line.
Is this a joke? They finally get to bits of text here and there:
This guy's got to be one of the best black ops agent we ever had. He's offed drug-lords, terrorists, heads of state. He's toppled governments.
Jesus. An ALARM from one of the computers sends Thomas back to check his system.  34.
I've got a ticket to Rio on Sarah Ross's credit card. They've been in the air three hours.
Three hours?
It looks like someone um... destroyed the airline's airport server. Cooper digests this, pissed.
He's running.
He's not running.
He knows we're going to be hard pressed to have someone there before him.
Does this look like the file of someone who's going to rabbit? It's a dodge. (beat) I get this guy. He's good. But he's old school. Cloak and dagger crap. He hardly knows how to use a computer.
He knows how to wreck one. Cooper shoots him a hard look, thinking it over.
If we hurt the woman's parents, do you think it will draw him out? This catches Thomas off guard.
I... don't know.
Put them under surveillance.
Frank and Sarah exit a terminal.
Car rental?
Long term parking.
Frank and Sarah step into the street in the "LONG TERM PARKING" lot. A GUY in a JEEP screeches to a halt and HONKS.
Move it!
We're in a crosswalk! The guy leans on his HORN and REVS his engine. Sarah jumps out of the way, but Frank just stands there, looking over the Jeep and its mullet-sporting driver.
Chop chop, Grandpa! Frank steps to the driver's side window. GUY (cont'd) What? You wanna go?
Is this thing 4-wheel drive?
Hell yeah.
Frank slams the trunk of a parked car on the duct-taped guy, climbs into the JEEP, smiles at Sarah and pulls out.
Heading south, Frank and Sarah are waved through to Mexic
Bouncing along this dirt road with the sun setting behind them, it feels a million miles from anywhere.  36. Up ahead, a walled compound rises out of the desert mesa.
When we get there, don't make any sudden movements. Don't ask to use a phone. In fact, don't even talk about phones. Or satellites. Sarah stares at him.
You're serious?

Yeah, why? Driving up to the front gate, they pull to a stop. FRANK (cont'd) (calling out) Hello? A little Mexican kid appears, pulling open the gate and excitedly waving them into the courtyard. Frank pulls forward... ...and suddenly the ground gives way and the entire Jeep collapses into a pit trap. Frank's instantly out the roof of the car, jumping clear. ...but as he hits the ground a FIGURE IN DESERT CAMO burs from a spider hole, leveling an assault rifle at Frank's head, screaming...
Jesus, Marvin! It's Frank!

head_text.subj: WHY ARE YOU TRYING TO KILL ME

text: I'm not!

You are! As Marvin's finger tightens on the trigger Frank lashes out, pulling the barrel past him and the fight is on. Marvin throws two quick punches, connecting hard, but Frank counters, sweeping a leg, and they land in a heap with Frank's .45 in Marvin's face.  37.

head_text.subj: WHY DO YOU THINK I AM TRYING TO

text: Because the last time we met, I tried to kill you. Frank considers.
That was a long time ago.
You sure? Some people hold onto a thing like that.
I am NOT trying to kill you! Marvin thinks it over and smiles.
Okay.

So get your knife out of my balls! REVEAL Marvin has a blade pressed to Frank's crotch. They slowly lower their weapons. Marvin helps Frank up, dusting him off. He's older than Frank, weathered, with wild hair and bright eyes. Reaching into the pit, Frank helps Sarah out of the car. FRANK (cont'd) Sarah, this is Marvin Frye. Marvin, she's okay. I promise.
Hello. Marvin eyes her with suspicion, then abruptly turns and starts out the front gate, walking into the desert.
Come on. I'll show you the house. Frank glances back at the beautiful hacienda behind them.
What's that? Marvin doesn't even turn around.  38.
The decoy.

A door in the ceiling opens and harsh sunlight breaks the darkness, revealing stairs running down cast concrete wal Marvin, Sarah and Frank make their way into the utilitari bunker, past barrels of water and fuel, MREs and dry good
Why do you live in a bunker when you have that other place?

I moved out last year after that helicopter flew by. (leaning close) I could feel their eyes on me, wet, like peaches. Sarah glances wide-eyed at Frank, but he waves her off with a "don't go there" gesture. Marvin leads them into the "living room," smiling geniall MARVIN (cont'd) So let me see this list. Frank hands it over as Sarah glances around uneasily at the ratty chairs and dozens of racks of firearms, crates of C-4, grenade launchers, and Stinger missiles.
Everyone on it's dead except for us and one other guy. I can't figure out the connection. Marvin paces as he studies the list, growing more and more agitated.

I always told you, Frank, you can't trust the system. You can't be a part of it, because then, the minute they flip the switch, you're done. The satellites, man, the cell phones, the chips, the net... Marvin drifts off, staring at nothing. Frank and Sarah exchange a look worried look.
Marvin.  39.
What?
The list. I need your help. Marvin looks at him, then back at the list, completely unaware of any break in continuity.
Let me check the files.

A steel door CREAKS open revealing a room that looks like the physical embodiment of a madman's mind. Towers of papers, clippings, scrawled notes, and typed summaries fill the room, floor to ceiling, flagged with color codes and numbers in some insane indexing system.
It's gotten bigger.
This may take a minute.
Frank walks back in. Sarah chases after him, eyeing the aluminum foil taped to the bunker's ceiling.
(whisper ) Frank. This guy's insane!
I told you: he sectioned out.
How am I supposed to know what that means?
Trust me, Marvin's the guy you want watching your back when everything goes to hell.
He said he tried to kill you!
I always felt bad about that.
What?
He thought he was the subject of a secret government mind control experiment. I told him he was nuts. He thought I was in on it and tried to kill me.
Jesus.
Yeah, but later I found out they were actually dosing him with LSD for a decade. Marvin walks back in with a stack of papers, Sarah.
Afghanistan. Fall of '81 near Ghazni. At least four of these guys were there, not including us. Frank thinks back, remembering. He looks at
What was it?
(hesitates) We were way out in the sticks and 40. startling Marvin. got called to meet this ISA Captain.
McGinty. He's on the list.
Two Mujahideen fighters walk along a rocky path into a narrow valley. On closer view, we see it's Frank and Marvin. and stare, sickened.
Holy Christ.

It was a village. Bloodied bodies lie everywhere. Men. Women. Animals. They stop Children.  41. Flies BUZZ obscenely. FRANK (V.0.) (cont'd) There were no military targets there. It was a massacre. Marvin examines a spent shell and tosses it to Frank. They exchange a concerned look. Stepping over bodies, they approach Special Forces CAPTAI McGINTY waiting for them beside a CIVILIAN, 30s, who incongruously wears a short-sleeved button-down.
What the hell happened here? But the civilian steps in front of him.
Your orders are to make this disappear. Bury the bodies. Burn everything else. Pick up every piece of American brass. This never happened. Frank just stares at the carnage.
Frank stares at Marvin.
You think everyone on this list was involved? Marvin shrugs, flipping through military records.
Even if there was some massacre, why do they want to kill you now?

You sure it's the CIA? Frank nods. Marvin paces, getting more and more worked up. MARVIN (cont'd) Dammit. DAMMIT! (beat) You know what's WRONG with this government -- with these Patriot Act wiretapping, preemptive war (more)  A beat as 42. MARVIN (cont'd) starting, extreme renditioning, fear-mongering War on Terror bastards?
They're trying to kill us?
Exactly! Frank waits for more.
It's why we're here, Marvin.
Well we've got to do something. (beat ) Who else on this list is still alive?
Gabriel Loeb.
Lock and load, baby! It's on!
Loud cars, thick pollution, and crowds of locals selling trinkets to crowds of American tourists fill the street.
Frank and Marvin sit in the shade, eating popsicles and watching Sarah talk on a pay phone across the street.

(agitated) What if they've tapped every data source that exists on this Loeb guy and are backtracing every connection that comes in on those sources and somehow filter those millions of calls and know it's us and then tag us with a chemical marker, or put a satellite on us, or fry us with Y-rays? Frank thinks it over.
Even for you that's pretty paranoid.  43.
I guess. Marvin glances up at the sky, then pulls out a tattered napkin and makes some urgent notes.
What are you doing?
(defensive) Nothing. Sarah hangs up and heads over. MARVIN (cont'd) What's with the girl, anyway?
I like her.
No seriously. What's the angle? Frank lets it go as Sarah walks up.
Loeb is coming into San Antonio. We can meet him at the Air Freight terminal. It's his first return to the country in four weeks. Marvin looks at Frank.
How do you want to cross the border?
Discreetly.

A group of noisy SENIOR TOURISTS carrying tons of cheap Juarez tourist crap disembark from a tour bus. Among them are Frank, wearing a serape, Sarah with a pig pifiata, and Marvin sporting a sombrero. A drunk OLD LADY swigs from a beer, singing at Marvin...
La cucaracha, la cucaracha, ya no puede caminar...  44.
Next time lets just hijack someone or blow something up.
Next time I get the serape.
I always get the serape.
He does. Walking away, Frank and Sarah head to a taxi stand and look around for a cab.
Oh no! Oh God! Please don't... Frank and Sarah spin, stunned to see... Marvin, holding a gun to the head of a BUSINESSWOMAN, dragging her into an alley.

(terrified) Coldwell Banker! I'ma real estate agent! Just take the money. Please don't hurt me! Furious at the lie, Marvin cocks the pistol, putting it to her eye, sending the woman erupting into tears as Fran and Sarah burst around the corner.
Hey!
Marvin! What are you...
One of who?
SHE WAS FOLLOWING US, MAN! She's got a camera hidden in her purse. (matter of fact) We have to kill her.  45.
(sobbing) No... please... Marvin holds up his left hand to block the splatter...
Frank!

Just hold on! He grabs the woman's purse and dumps the contents onto the ground: there's a wallet, cosmetics, a cell phone. Frank rips the purse apart: there's nothing. FRANK (cont'd) (annoyed) Where's the camera, Marvin? Marvin hesitates, suddenly unsure.
She was... following us. Frank pushes down the barrel of Marvin's gun and snaps the woman's cell phone in half.
(to the woman) Go. She runs off. Frank gives Marvin a hard look. FRANK (cont'd) Go get us a car. And don't kill anyone.
Sarah and Frank watch a 747 cargo jet pull to a stop on the tarmac and power down. Marvin's in the background with the pifiata, absentminded scratching it behind the ears. Sarah's quiet. Angry.
Are you upset?
"She's got a camera hidden in her purse. We have to kill her." Are you kidding me?  46.

Everyone makes mistakes. He stands, cutting off Sarah's retort as three PILOTS enter the terminal. FRANK (cont'd) Gabriel Loeb? The oldest pilot looks over. He's Frank's age with that classic ex-military look: tight haircut, thin, good shape The other two pilots pause as well, but Gabriel nods to them to go on ahead. FRANK (cont'd) You have a minute?
(Texas twang) What's this about?
Afghanistan. 1981. Near Ghazni. There's a tense beat.
I can't talk to you. He pushes past, but Marvin steps in front of him. In a flash, Gabriel has a knife in his hand. Marvin and Frank both draw guns. Gabriel smiles. GABRIEL (cont'd) Pair beats ace.
They walk Gabriel into this second story windowed office looking out over the airfield. Marvin circles the room, looking out the windows.
You fellas hear the one about what the West Texas Jew-boy twice- decorated Marine pilot said to the Chinese New York Times reporter?
What?  47.
Nothing! I didn't tell her a damned thing! Frank looks at him coldly.
She's dead. And everyone on her list is dead except for you, me, and him. The CIA has targeted everyone who was there. Gabriel's stunned.
Oh Christ. Frank stares at him realizing...
You know why... Gabriel sits down heavily, unable to look at him. FRANK (cont'd) Tell me. He glances up with fear and resignation.
They had me fly this guy out there from the gulf. Middle of the night. Hairy little airstrip in the middle of nowhere. He picked up a package and we flew back out.
Who was the guy? Over by the windows, Marvin starts MUTTERING as he fidget with his tattered napkin. Sarah glances over nervously.
CIA. Dorky little spook in short sleeves straight out of some office. The whole thing was super hush hush.
What about the package?
Frank! Frank! Frank
(annoyed) What?  48. Marvin runs over, pointing out the window.
A helicopter!
We're at an airport for Christ's sake.

Two four seven seven one. It's following us. I write down all the numbers, see? Frank stares at Marvin, then looks at the tattered napkin filled with dozens of rows of tiny, smeared numbers. He squints at the chopper then back at the napkin.
That's a four.
It's a seven!
Who makes a seven like that?
Let me see it. Suddenly the window SPIDERWEBS. Sarah looks around, startled.

Whoa! What was...? She realizes Frank, Marvin and Gabriel are on the floor. Frank pulls her down as... WHUMP! A bullet hits the wall where she was standing. Gabriel lies motionless, blood on his shirt. SARAH (cont'd) Oh my God! Frank checks him. Dead.
I knew we shouldn't have used that phone!
Shut up, Marvin!  49.
Cooper listens in on a comm set as he watches a LONG-LENS VIDEO FEED of the unfolding action with Thomas and Jackso
One target down. I have no visual.
Fire for effect.

Gunfire FLASH-FRAMES the SILENT footage as the shooter unloads, bullets chewing up the windows of the building. Frank runs low and fast through the air cargo office, dragging Sarah after him as she holds onto the pifiata.
Targets exiting south side.

Frank, Sarah and Marvin burst into this warehouse alley. Suddenly someone steps around the corner up ahead with an assault rifle, firing. It's the "businesswoman" Marvin grabbed earlier. They dive behind a dumpster, bullets SLAMMING all around.
I'm going to fuck you up, old man! Marvin gives Frank a look.
Can I kill her now? Together as one, they swing around opposite sides of the dumpster to fire... But she's gone.
Move! Marvin covers the rear as Frank pushes Sarah up the alley  50.
Suddenly their flight is interrupted as BULLETS RAIN DOWN from a ROOFTOP SHOOTER, sending all three diving for cove behind a scissor lift.
(re: pifiata) Give me the pig. Sarah hands it over and... WHACK! Frank punches in the side, pulling out extra magazines. Marvin reaches in, coming up with a machine pistol.

Old man? I'm in my prime! Frank scoffs. Pissed, Marvin jacks a cartridge out of his gun, catches it in the air and holds it out. MARVIN (cont'd) Bet you can't take this bullet out of my hand. More bullets SLAM around them.
Not now, Marvin!
Bet you can't. Quick as a flash, Sarah grabs the bullet.
Can we go now! Marvin is stunned.

WAIT! I wasn't ready. Do it again. Under a barrage of lead, Frank leans around the scissor lift, takes his time, and fires a single shot, ending the incoming fire. Suddenly BLAM BLAM BLAM... bullets fly out of the wall, beside them, just missing. Stunned, Frank and Marvin FIRE BACK THROUGH THE WALL.
Aaaagh!  51.
How the hell...?
Satellites. He looks up at the sky and flips it off.
Cooper watches the big screen which has up a satellite picture of the area with red thermal signatures of the people on the ground, including Marvin and his finger.
Two men down. Jackson sees something on screen.
Hold on, this is going to be good.
At the far end of the alley, the "businesswoman" steps around the corner with a shoulder-mounted rocket.

That's not good. Frank grabs her, running all-out down the alley. FFFSST! KABOOM! The scissor-lift explodes like a toy. Frank and Sarah are thrown to the ground by the blast. Reloading, the woman levels the launcher again at the prone figures. But suddenly Marvin steps from the burning debris, standi his ground, facing her down like a gunfighter. The woman's finger tightens on the trigger... And in a single clean motion, Marvin raises his pistol and fires. KA-BOOOM! A massive explosion rocks the alley as his bullet detonates the rocket. As debris rains down on Frank and Sarah, a figure appears above them. It's Marvin, reaching down to help them up.
Old man, my ass.  52.
Everyone stares at the big screen, washed out by the thermals and smoke.
I can't see anything.
Get someone in there. I want to see bodies.
A food service truck drives away from the airport as a string of emergency vehicles speeds the other direction.
Marvin sleeps in the cab as Frank stands with Sarah at the side of the road, holding back her hair as she throws up in the tall grass.

I told you excitement was overrated. (beat ) You okay? She nods, then hurls again. FRANK (cont'd) It happens to everybody in the beginning. Frank looks over at Marvin who cracks one eye and taps his watch impatiently. Frank shrugs helplessly. Finally Sarah straightens up.
You sure know how to show a girl a good time. Are all your first dates like this? Frank's a deer in the headlights.
I uh... haven't dated much.
I don't believe it.  53.
Frank sits beside Marvin, who chuckles to himself as they roll through the night.
What's that?
(mimicking Frank) I uh... haven't dated much. Frank glares at him.
Don't make me shoot you. Marvin is positively gleeful.
It's okay, man. She likes you.
You think?
Notice how she's sticking around. Women don't do that if they don't like you.
She doesn't have a lot of choice.

Sure she does. Frank glances up at the far end of the car, watching Sara enter and make her way towards them. MARVIN (cont'd) They know we know about the list now. They're going to keep coming. Frank considers.
There's only one way we're going to find out what this is really about. Marvin weighs it.
It's impossible. We'll get killed for sure.  54.
So you're in?
Of course I'm in. I was just saying. Arriving beside Frank and Marvin, Sarah hands out candy to the fellas. She looks between them.
What?
Frank's behind the wheel, Sarah's in front, and Marvin's in back as they roll past the mall.
If we're going to pull this off, we're going to need help.
Pull what off? Frank stops across from a large compound. Marvin freaks.
No way! Not them!
Who? Marvin jumps out of the car. Resigned, Frank gets out. Sarah follows and sees the sign: RUSSIAN FEDERATION EMBAS
Godless bastards! He runs off down the street.
What's happening?
Marvin tends to be ruled by his emotions, but sometimes you need to think outside the box.
You're not really going in there?  55. Frank takes out his .45 and the dog tags he retrieved from his basement.
Hold these. (beat) In case I don't come back. She stares at him stunned. Frank presses them into her hands. For a long moment neither of them moves. Then Frank turns away, starting up the street.

Hey. He turns back and she's right there. Reaching up on tiptoes, she gives him a kiss on the cheek SARAH (cont'd) Be careful. He looks at her for a long beat, then turns, walking past the main gates, stopping at an unmarked steel door. Pressing an intercom button, he looks up at the camera.

Tell Ivan Siderov that Frank Moses is here to see him. There's no response. Up the street, Sarah stands in the shadows watching. Suddenly the door bursts open and four soldiers are leveling AK-47s at Frank. They expertly force him to kneel, pat him down, then roughly drag him inside. The last soldier stands in the doorway, rifle aimed at Sarah. She stands frozen, unable to breathe... ...and then he's gone.

IVAN SIDEROV, a rumpled old man, sits behind a large desk wearing a permanent expression of Russian pain and dissatisfaction, along with an expensively tailored suit that still manages to look like it doesn't fit.  56. Cleaning his nails, he doesn't even look up as Frank is dragged into the room and stuffed into a chair across from him.

Leave us. The soldiers look at him in surprise. He doesn't repeat himself, but raises his eyes to them and they file out. IVAN (cont'd) (heavy Russian accent) I have to say, this is not something I expected when I got up this morning. Ivan pulls a vodka bottle from a drawer, pours two, and slides one across the desk. He raises his glass. IVAN (cont'd) It is good to meet you. In person. They clink and drink.
Do you kind of want to shoot me? Ivan smiles.
Little bit. I used to dream about it. Like I dream about good coffee or sunshine during winter. But now, what's the point? You are retired, yes?
Yes. Ivan looks off.
Still, I feel I owe you for killing Semyon.
The Butcher?
A great asset. Did you know he was my cousin?
(a beat) No.  57.
(raising his glass) To Semyon the Butcher. Frank toasts and drinks. Then...
He's not actually dead. Ivan stares at Frank. FRANK (cont'd) I flipped him.
No...
Now he owns a bunch of 7-11s. Ivan looks at him, stunned. Frank smiles.
Bastard.
Yeah, well, I'm sure you've heard worse. Ivan fills Frank's glass.
I pour you double.
Why's that?
Veronique: that girl in Paris in "81. She was mine.
Impossible.
Da!
No.
Yes! He thinks it over.
Whatever she got, it was worth it.  58. They raise glasses and drink again. Ivan sits back.
I miss the old days. We could swing at each other like men. Now it's economic leverage and political posturing. I haven't had someone killed in years. Frank nods in sympathy.
What can you do?

And don't get me started on the puppies they send me to train now: too smart for their own good without a gram of sense among them. Ivan fills the glasses again. IVAN (cont'd) So. (beat ) I think that you are not here for the hospitality. There's a pregnant beat.
I'm going to break into the CIA. I need your complete security package on Langley: plans, schedules, cracks, IDs, all of it. Ivan stares at him.
Why would you possibly think I have that sort of information? There's a tense beat. Then they both chuckle. IVAN (cont'd) Why do this?
Personal project. Like a hobby. A beat.
Have you tried gardening?  59.
Didn't work out.
I can't stand it either. If it's not bugs, it's the damned fungus.
You try soapy water?
Does that work?
So I hear.
Sarah paces back and forth in the shadows across the stre from the main gate, alone, sick with worry. She starts towards the Embassy, but then stops, changes her mind, and doubles back.
I told you everything was going to be all right. She whips around as he appears from the shadows.
No you didn't! You said, "Hold these in case I don't come back."
So you were worried about me? Now she's embarrassed. She punches him in the arm.
Jerk. Frank smiles.
Let's go find Marvin.

Nestled on lush grounds, the old CIA headquarters buildin stands flanked by the two new massive six-story buildings where thousands of people come to work each day. The sprawling compound looks more like a college campus than the epicenter of American foreign intelligence.  60.

A towncar pulls up. Marvin gets out and opens the door for Frank and Sarah, who exit wearing suits and CIA badge As the two of them walk toward one of the towers, Sarah looks like she's going to be sick.
I can't do this.
Just relax and smile. I'll get us inside, you'll just pull their files.
I'm not a hacker.
It's a closed system. The trick is getting to the terminal.
Frank and Sarah enter and make their way through the huge four-story atrium, towards the high-security elevators. An armed guard looks them over. Sarah forces a smile.
What makes you think the Russians wouldn't sell you down the river?
Ivan and I come from a world where enemies can still have ethics. I guess you could say, I have faith.
Faith? Frank hands Sarah a small case and punches the elevator button.
Actually it's more like hope.

Stepping inside, Frank punches in a security code and the button for the 5th floor. The door slides closed and the wall-mounted retinal scann lights up as Sarah opens the case, removing a single gold contact lens, laser-etched with an elaborate pattern.  61. Frank bends close and she puts the contact...
I dropped it. Frank looks at her stunned.
What?
I dropped it!
Scan incomplete. They both drop to the floor, frantically searching.
Gently.
Dammit...
Scan incomplete.
I don't know how long... An ALARM suddenly sounds.

Oh God, oh God... The doors roll open and THREE SECURITY OFFICERS stand ready, hands on their weapons, looking down at Frank and Sarah on all fours. There's a seriously awkward beat. SARAH (cont'd) The General dropped his contact. Frank looks at her in disbelief. SARAH (cont'd) (annoyed) Well? Aren't you going to give him a hand? Frank watches stunned as the security officers quickly join them on all fours, searching the floor.
Got it!  62. He holds up the contact to the light, looking closely... ...but Sarah snatches it.
Here, sir. Quickly cleaning it, she gently lays it in Frank's eye. The lead security officer turns a key in the elevator, and Frank leans forward to have his eye scanned.
Scan complete. The lights go green.
Have a good day, sir. Frank nods and the doors roll closed.
I don't begin to know what to say about that.
Frank leads Sarah to a heavy steel door with an elaborate electronic number pad/scanner beside it.
Is this it? Frank nods.
Did you know these locks cost eighty- five thousand dollars each?
No. He pulls out a matt knife and cuts a hole in the drywall beside the door, then reaches in and opens the handle.

God love forced low-bid government contracts. He tapes a single sheet of paper over the hole in the wall: "SECURITY IS EVERYONE'S BUSINESS." Pushing open the door reveals a small, high-tech room with a lone computer terminal.  63.
Sarah sits at the computer with Frank behind her, watchin her fly through files and directories.
What do you think the punishment is for what we're doing?
Depending on what they charge you with, either life in prison or death.
Awesome. She brings up the profile for the killer dressed as a young cop who tried to grab her at the motel. SARAH (cont'd) There.
Work the assignment tree back and see if you can find the executive. A few keystrokes later, she brings up Cooper's photograph and profile. FRANK (cont'd) I want everything on this guy.
Thomas stares at his computer, flipping out.
Someone's tripping flags in the system. They're all over our players! Cooper's at his side in a second.
Who is it? Thomas looks from his screen in confusion...
It's internal. Directorate on five. Cooper hustles across the room and grabs a phone.
We have a breach on five.  64.
BOOM! SIX TACTICAL BADASSES in body armor burst into the secure server room leveling weapons. Sarah whips around..

BOOM! Frank kicks open the door, bursting inside. Thomas makes it to his feet before his face is bounced into the desk and he hits the floor unconscious. Frank looks at Cooper across the room, still on the phone
You. Cooper stares. He almost laughs.
Unbelievable. Frank closes in on him.
What did they pull out of Afghanistan?
(incredulous) You think you can just walk in here and everyone'll just roll over?

Actually, I figured I'd have to beat it out of some snot-nosed button-pusher. Frank swings on him, but Cooper blocks and counters. In a flurry of fists, Frank is hit once and then again. Face bloodied, he stumbles back, stunned. Cooper smiles.
Not quite as fast as you once were? Frank spits blood.
Kordesky trained you?
Yeah.  65. Cooper closes again, attacks, blocks, and delivers two more brutal body-blows... ...but suddenly Frank spins around him, catching an arm and slamming Cooper onto a desk, pinned.
I taught Kordesky. Frank brutally twists his arm, tighter.
Who ordered these hits? Cooper glares back at him.
Orders come, you execute. You of all people should know how it works. CRACK! Frank breaks his arm. COOPER (cont'd)
You come after one of your own and you don't even ask why?

It doesn't come to me unless it's been vetted all the way up the line. There's not a doubt in my mind you've earned what you've got coming. Frank grabs his chin, cranking his neck to the edge of breaking.
The minute you learned who I was you should have walked away. Gasping, Cooper wrenches out a reply.

Would you? Suddenly wrenching to his left, Cooper slides off the desk, hitting the floor, catching Frank by surprise with a kick, knocking him down. Jumping up, Cooper grabs a phone with his good arm, clobbering Frank...  66. ...but Frank kicks him, catching Cooper in the gut, sendi him flying backwards through the glass wall of his office Frank's up in a second, but Cooper's in his desk, coming up with a gun. Frank ducks, running for the door as Cooper UNLOADS. Rounds chew up the wall behind him... then slam into him, spilling Frank out the door. Cooper races after, bursting into the hall... But it's empty except for a spatter of blood.

Frank's hit in the shoulder and the side, in pain, forcin himself down the stairs. Stepping into the 4th floor hall, he pulls the first fire alarm he sees. As ALARMS RING, he presses forward through the rapidly filling corridor and catches a woman by the arm:
Where's the server room?
End of the hall. (seeing the blood) My God... But he's already in motion.
Rows of servers fill this clean room, but Frank ignores them, arriving at the "FIRE CONTROL ROOM" off to one side
Opening the door reveals a small room filled with gas cylinders marked "HALON" surrounded by warning signs.

As ALARMS CONTINUE TO RING, Sarah is frog-marched by two tactical badasses down this hall, hands zip-cuffed behind her back.  67. Rounding a corner, they are suddenly right in front of Frank standing beside a Halon canister with a fire axe. Frank takes a deep breath and swings, snapping the valve. PRESSURIZED GAS ERUPTS and suddenly Sarah and her escorts are writhing on the ground gasping for air that doesn't seem to be there. Frank wades in, cuts Sarah's zip cuffs and picks her up.
Frank drags Sarah up the stairs.
Breathe out then in. You're fine. Just breathe. Gasping, she follows his directions, gaining control.
You're bleeding!
Do you have the download? She pulls a memory stick from her bra.

They emerge into the open hall overlooking the four story atrium where ALARMS continue to RING. Dozens of people fill the hall trying to figure out what' happening as emergency vehicles pull up out front. Security is everywhere. They're screwed.
What are we going to do? Frank leads her forward to where he's stashed a second canister of Halon. SARAH (cont'd) What is that?
It binds up oxygen in the air. Kicking it over he gets it rolling and... SMASH! The canister breaks through the glass panel under the railing, falls three stories and...  68.
Suddenly everyone is gasping and screaming, choking, flipping out. She looks at him in horror. FRANK (cont'd) Relax. It's just uncomfortable; feels like nerve gas.

Cooper stands outside the HQ buildings, scanning faces as people stream out, desperately searching for Frank. But PULLING BACK reveals there are THOUSANDS of workers flooding from the buildings. It's hopeless.

Frank and Sarah separate from the crowd, Frank leaning heavily on Sarah as they make their way towards the townc at the back of the lot. Marvin's behind the wheel, ramrod stiff, sunglasses on, staring straight ahead.
Marvin, help me. But Marvin doesn't move. Getting closer, they see he's handcuffed to the steering wheel with a gun pressed to the back of his head.
Hold up! The back window rolls down revealing... ...JOE MATHESON. Frank can't believe it. FRANK (cont'd) Joe!
(nods at Marvin) There's something wrong with this guy, Frank, you know, in the head. Frank grins.  69.
Yeah. I know. (beat) You okay, Marvin?
I don't want to talk about it.
Help him in here, honey. Sarah pulls open the door and settles Frank into the car beside Joe.
I thought you were dead.
Joe kicks his wheelchair around to face the two killers. They're astonished to see he's got a 9mm semiautomatic in each hand.

Nah. Just retired. (to Marvin) Start the car, nutjob. Sarah closes the door and rounds the car heading for the front seat. JOE (cont'd) She's with you? Frank nods. JOE (cont'd) Nice work. Sarah slides in and Marvin pulls out.

DIRECTOR OF OPERATIONS, GARY STEVENS, storms down the hall trailed by several AIDES and a SECURITY DETAIL. He's the man from the park who gave Cooper his assignment but now he seems overwhelmed to the point of breaking.
They don't know how he did it yet. We're in lockdown.  70.
Are we safe?
They don't believe he's still on site.
(to Aide #1) I have the Director of National Intelligence calling for the Director of Operations.
I'll call back. Wait here. Leaving the entourage, he pushes through a door into...
Debris is strewn everywhere. Cooper, arm splinted, gets up to face Stevens.
How the fuck did this happen? Do you understand the ramifications of this breach? How this makes us look? The attention this attracts?
Sir...

Shut up. You just got your high- tech ass handed to you by your target. A retiree with zero resources. A man deemed too old to work in the field. Cooper's phone RINGS. He kills it. DIRECTOR OF OPERATIONS STEVENS (cont'd) I am NOT about to get hung out to dry. Do I need to get involved? Get someone else?
No sir. Cooper's phone RINGS again and is silenced.
I want this guy dead. I don't care if it's messy. Take whatever assets you need and finish it.  71. He turns and leaves.
Cooper stalks down the hall, furious. His phone RINGS again and he picks up.
Cooper.
You must be talking to someone important. Cooper goes cold. FRANK (V.0.) (cont'd) I was just calling to let you know there's a new list. And you're right at the top. CLICK. The line goes dead.
Frank closes the phone.
Psyops! Hell yeah.
Both hands on the wheel, Nutjob. Sarah turns to Joe.
The bleeding won't stop. We need to get help. Joe looks at Frank.
I know a place.
They pull up outside this cute little B&B on the Maryland coast with gorgeous ocean views and a stunning garden.  72.
I'll go in alone, see if we can stay.
Don't be ridiculous. I'1l go. Joe puts a hand on her arm. SARAH (cont'd) (realizing) Is this a thing? This is a thing isn't it? Everybody knows but me?
It'll be fine. Frank and Marvin exchange a look.
You want a vest?
Wouldn't make any difference.

Frank enters, the bell on the door JINGLING brightly. The place is adorable. VICTORIA sits in the dining room folding napkins. A littl older than Frank, she's prim, proper, and beautiful. She looks up, surprised. Then smiles.
(English accent) Frank Moses.
Victoria.
It's been a long time.
Yeah. There's a beat between them.
Are you here to kill me?  73.
No. I need your help. He slowly opens his jacket, revealing no weapons, but a lot of blood. She sighs, possibly disappointed...

Oh. ...and sets aside the HIGH CAPACITY MACHINE PISTOL she was concealing behind the stack of napkins. VICTORIA (cont'd) Come on in, then. And tell Marvin to stand down before he gets hurt. Frank glances out the window where Marvin sits in her rose bushes covering the action.
By the way, your roses are fabulous.
The others filter in and Joe and Victoria embrace.
Joseph.
Victoria. You're lovely as ever.
You old snake charmer. Sarah looks between them all, a little lost.
So. How do you all know each other?
Victoria was the best wet asset I ever worked with. A true artist with a PSG. Sarah shoots Frank a questioning look.
(aside) Killer. Very dangerous. Sarah smiles at Victoria, uneasy. She smiles back, warmly  74.
I'm gonna scout the perimeter.
Just mind the daisies.
Frank and Victoria sit alone as she peers through reading glasses, expertly working on Frank's shoulder with forcep and a sponge.
I'd better hurry this along or I'll be late with four o'clock tea. Frank studies her, impressed.
How did you do it?
What?
Make the transition? You have a beautiful place here. A nice quiet life. You seem so at ease. He winces as Victoria extracts the bullet.
I try. But it's not easy. Sometimes I get restless. (confessing) I still take the occasional contract on the side.
You do?
(hesitates, guilty) I can't seem to stop. I miss the rush. They retire us, but you can't just flip a switch and become someone else, you know. She starts stitching up Frank's shoulder.
I didn't know what to do with myself. All I ever had was work. (more)  75. FRANK (cont'd) And suddenly there was so much time. (beat) I've done so many terrible things.
We did them for good reasons. A beat.
Maybe. I'm starting to wonder.
Tell me about Sarah. Frank looks uncomfortable: much more so then when she was pulling lead out of him.
She makes me feel like maybe I could have a different life. Like normal people. Victoria smiles.
It's one of the reasons I've always been so fond of you, Francis: you're a romantic.
What?
Hard on the outside. Gooey on the inside.
Get outta here.
Gooey.
Marvin, Joe, Frank, Sarah and Victoria sit around the coffee table with papers and a laptop. Other guests chat quietly in the background.
This is the reporter's list. This is the hit list we downloaded from the CIA. (more)  76. SARAH (cont'd) They're the same except there's one name that's not on the hit dist: Andrew Dunning.
Christ. He's CEO of Browning-Orvis.
Who?
The defense contractor. Very politically connected.
Let's pay him a visit. Victoria pours more coffee.
You know, business is a little slow right now... Frank smiles wide.
Cooper sits in his suburban living room, reading Frank's file as his wife, ELIZABETH, walks in, dressed for bed.
What are you working on?
Just trying to figure someone out. My arm hurts too much to sleep anyway.
I hope you learned your lesson playing basketball with those Marines. Cooper gets up and gives her a kiss.
Yes dear. She swats him and he pushes her back towards their room. COOPER (cont'd) Come on, I'll tuck you in. Halfway down the back hall, he pauses at a door, silently cracking it open.  77.
He looks in on his two boys, asleep in a bunk bed, each wearing different superhero pajamas. Cooper silently closes the door.
Sarah stands on the balcony, looking out at the water. In the room behind her, Frank's cleaning his .45, but she can feel his eyes on her.
Penny for your thoughts?
I was just wondering how you're holding up. TI know it's a lot. Sarah smiles.

I've never been so scared in my life as today. But it was unbelievable. I'm okay. He nods, then goes back to work reassembling the gun. She watches him for a moment. SARAH (cont'd) Why don't you walk away? You could disappear, right? Frank finishes what he's doing and puts the gun down.

Hide and go set up somewhere else? She nods. FRANK (cont'd) Dragging you along on this, I think about it. But letting this happen, then and now, I can't. She comes inside, picking up the cot that has been wedged into the room and moving it along one wall.
I think you should sleep in the bed tonight.  78.
Don't be silly.
That's not what I meant.
I don't understand.
Come here and let me explain it to you. Reaching out, she takes his shirt and pulls him into a kiss.
This epic mansion sits behind gated walls, surrounded by tennis courts, a pool, a helicopter pad, guest houses, and rolling lawns from the woods down to the water.
Frank sits with his back against a tree as Marvin checks it out with binoculars. They're both clad in black.
Rent-a-cops. Video. Infrared alarms. All the usual crap.
Sarah lies in the dirt beside Victoria who sets up a camo draped rifle almost as tall as she is.
Frank said you wanted me with you.

He thought it would be safer and I thought it would be fun to have a little girl time; get to know each other, talk about the boys. Plus I wanted you to know that in all the years I've known Francis, I've never seen him like this, so if you break his heart, I'll kill you and bury your body in the woods. Sarah looks at her, stunned. Victoria smiles.  79. VICTORIA (cont'd) This is going to be fun.
A security guard escorts Joe, in his wheelchair and three piece suit, up to the main house.
A butler leads the way into a sumptuous study: hardwood, heavy furniture, and leather.
Nice place. In fact, I'm not sure I've ever been in a room this nice. ANDREW DUNNING, portly and rich, sits behind his desk, looking Joe over skeptically. JOE (cont'd) How big is that TV?
What can I do for you, Mr. Matheson, was it? Joe grins.

We just have a few questions. Suddenly Frank appears behind the startled butler, quickl zip-tying his hands. Marvin appears in another doorway, hustling in three security guards, their hands zip-tied behind their backs.
Put them with the others. Dunning looks between them angrily as Frank cuffs him into his chair.
Who are you?
You don't remember me? (beat ) I remember you.  80.
The man wearing a short sleeved civilian button-down step towards young Frank and Marvin. He's put on weight and lost hair, but the man is Dunning.
Tell us what happened in Afghanistan. A beat as this registers.
You can't touch me. You have no idea what you're dealing with. Frank glances at Marvin walking back in.
We have any idea what we're dealing with?
Not really. Maybe a little.
Can we touch him?
Definitely. Frank starts unpacking a bag: blowtorch, drain cleaner, Vice Grips...
(to Dunning) Did you know that Frank here wrote the CIA field manual on torture? The old one.
Wait. Hold on a minute... Frank fires up the blowtorch.
I like this one. Where'd you get it? Dunning stares in fear.
Home Depot. Twelve bucks.  81.
No kidding. Frank holds out the torch and Marvin puts a pair of Vice Grips in the flame.
They glance over as though seeing Dunning for the first time. DUNNING (cont'd) I ran the Afghan operation.
What did you take out of there?
It wasn't a what. It was a who...
YOUNG GABRIEL LOEB glances back out the cockpit door as Dunning drags aboard a YOUNG SOLDIER with a thousand yard stare, covered in blood and dirt.
We extracted a young Second Lieutenant. He was the son of then Senator, Henry Stanton.
This quietly sinks in.
Robert Stanton.
The Vice President of the United States? Dunning nods.
Holy crap.
He was responsible for what happened there?
That's what the New York Times reporter wanted to know.  82.
What did you tell her?
I said I didn't know anything about it.
Then you called the Vice President.
(defensive) Of course. Our families have been friends for years.

head_text.subj: WHAT DID YOU THINK WAS GOING TO

text: He ordered everyone killed. Except you.
I didn't know that! Victoria's voice interrupts, crackling over the radio.
We have major activity on the perimeter. Somebody serious is setting up shop. Dunning smiles at Frank, cocky once again.
You're finished. The Company's had me under surveillance since your little stunt over there.
Victoria lies dead still, sighting through her scope as Sarah fidgets nervously.
I don't see how you can be so calm. Victoria smiles.
So how did you two meet? This isn't what she expected, but Sarah allows herself to be deflected.  83.
We just started talking. There was something about him... (beat) Of course, now I'm a fugitive, the CIA wants to kill me, and I'm hiding in a hole.
I was in love once, with an agent.
What happened?
The relationship wasn't sanctioned. When it came to light, my loyalty was questioned. I was told to kill him. It was a test. She says it all so matter of factly. Sarah looks at her stunned.
What did you do?
I put three rounds in his chest.
Heavily armed COMMANDOS in body armor and black continue to unload from FBI vans as the FBI COMMANDER wades throug the deployment, finding Cooper and handing him a phone.
We're in position, sir. Perimeter's set. No one's getting out.
Marvin lies on the floor peering out a window.
How's it look?
Remember the Alamo?

They have sniper positions on North, West, and East sides. (more)  84. VICTORIA (V.0.) (cont'd) Ground personnel in force out front and backup in the rear. I'd estimate sixty total. The phone on the desk begins to RING. Frank picks it up.
I've been reading your file.
Learn anything about how to be an agent yet? Cooper's calm and even, pacing as he talks.

You've done a lot of service for this country. And when I put that together with your CIA visit where the only person that got hurt was me - I would say you value American lives. (beat) But if we come through that door, people are going to get hurt.
I expect so.
You don't want that.
I didn't start this.
I have orders.

They're coming from the Vice President. He ordered these hits to cover up war crimes he committed in Afghanistan in September 1981. (beat) I buried the bodies in '81. They have you doing it now. You're killing everyone who was there. Cooper doesn't bat an eye.  85.
I don't believe that.
If you did, would it matter? Cooper thinks it over, weighing it out.
Yes.
So what do you propose to do about that?
You give yourself up. I'1l take you into custody. You'll get to tell your side of the story. Frank smiles grimly.
Sure I will. Even if you brought me in, someone would just put a bullet in my head.
That's not true.
If you actually believe that, you're even more naive than I thought.
You're surrounded. The FBI is going to take you apart. There is no exit here. But how it goes down is up to you. Cooper hangs up.
Frank watches Marvin laying out his numerous weapons. Joe puts a hand on Frank's shoulder.
We don't have a lot of options, Kid.
Yeah.  86.

Somebody's going to have to make the tough choice if any of us are going to make it out alive. A long, quiet moment of understanding passes between them love and sadness. JOE (cont'd) I think you're going to have to give yourself up. Finally Frank nods.
Cooper's phone RINGS. He answers.
Hold your fire, I'm coming out. Frank hangs up.

All units hold fire. Repeat hold all fire. He's coming out. 200 yards out, Cooper watches the front door of the house open and a lone, black-clad figure steps out, hands raise CRACK! A shot rings out. Frank falls. Stunned, Cooper looks around furious... COOPER (cont'd) Who fired that shot? No one says anything. COOPER (cont'd)

He turns, reeling, realizing Frank was right: he's not in control of this situation. Cooper draws his weapon and charges towards the house. Frank lies motionless on the walkway. Cooper rolls the body over. It's Joe Matheson, dressed in Frank's clothes. He's dead.  87. PUSH IN on Cooper. Suddenly GUNFIRE erupts from the back of the house, and RADIOS ARE SCREAMING.
FBI sniper teams are taking fire! Two suspects have broken perimeter!
Hell...
Frank and Marvin race across an open field, making for the woods in the distance.
An FBI sniper and his spotter squirm down into their cove as rounds SLAP into the ground inches from them.
Victoria lies prone, coolly squeezing off round after round keeping the sniper teams scrambling for cover.

Now isn't this worth sitting ina hole for? Sarah looks at her like she's insane. VICTORIA (cont'd) Keep an eye on the boys. When they make cover, we move. Suddenly they're taking SMALL ARMS FIRE. Victoria whips around, firing back, pulling Sarah up and pushing her into a run.
Frank and Marvin hit the cover of the woods and immediate change direction, scrambling uphill.
A dozen men charge towards the woods in pursuit.  88.

Sarah runs just ahead of Victoria, crashing through the forest... ...Straight into the arms of a black-clad COMMANDO. He pins her, covering her mouth as his three partners cover the woods behind her, scoping for Victoria. ...but there is nothing but SILENCE.
Frank slips over the wall, Marvin just behind him. Sneaking up the perimeter, they suddenly raise weapons... ...and Victoria slips from the shadows with her rifle.

They have Sarah. Frank turns back to the estate wall: he's going over. VICTORIA (cont'd) You can't. (beat) How many are you willing to kill? SOUNDS RISE as people crash through the underbrush behind them. Up the road, other forces are closing in. VICTORIA (cont'd) Live to fight another day, Francis. Sickened, Frank knows she's right.
Two of the COMMANDOS move in, covering the room. Dunning sits cuffed in his chair.
Clear!
Mr. Dunning?
Yes. Thank God.  89. FSST!  FSST! The commando fires twice from a SILENCED pistol.

Leading the way out of the woods, Frank pauses at the edge of a creek and a small country road. A helicopter flies overhead, searchlight cutting the darkness. And directly across from them a limo sits under the trees The door opens and out steps Ivan Siderov.
Come! Now is not time to waste.
How. ..? The Russian smiles wide.
You are not the only country with satellites.
(aside to Frank) Why would he be helping us..? But Ivan is staring at Victoria.
Zaychick moy. She smiles back.
Hello Ivan. It's good to see you. Frank looks between them.
Did he just call you... bunny?
Life, sometimes, is complicated.  90.

Victoria sits on the wide arm of Frank's chair, changing the dressings on his wounds. Through it all she somehow still manages to look stunning. Marvin's off to one side, staring out into the night. Ivan puts the finishing touches on a pitcher of martinis and pours a round.
To Joe. Everyone raises their glasses.
To Joe.
A life of service and sacrifice. They drink. It's a long somber beat. Finally Victoria breaks the silence.
Does anyone want to discuss the fact that we're all dead?
It ain't over till it's over.
The CIA's being used as the Vice President's personal hit squad. It's a bit of a conversation crusher. Ivan holds up the pitcher.
Anyone like another? Victoria and Marvin raise their glasses.
They say he's going to run for President.  91.
I don't think it's possible to outrun this. It's only a matter of time until they find us.
You could come to Mother Russia.
When hell freezes over.
St. Petersburg in the spring is very beautiful.
Anyone else? They think it over.
Veritas vos liberabit. The truth will set you free.
Tell people?
It's a thought.

What about Frank's girlfriend? What's her name? The cute one. They'd kill her so fast. Of course they might have already. But they'll interrogate her first. In fact, she's probably getting waterboarded right now...
Marvin.
What? He looks over at Frank who gets up, heading inside. MARVIN (cont'd) Oh.
Frank stands at the kitchen sink as Ivan walks in.
You okay?  92.
No.

I want to show you something. He starts unbuttoning his shirt. IVAN (cont'd) Don't get too excited. Pulling it open reveals old scars from three bullet wound IVAN (cont'd) This was done to me by the love of my life. It seemed that what we had was not meant to be. But now she is sitting in my house drinking vodka.
Victoria?

Three bullets in the chest. But when I woke up alive, I knew that she still loved me - or it would have been the head. Frank can't help but smile. Ivan buttons his shirt.
